A modified Atwood machine consists of two masses, M = 5.0 kg and m = 3.0 kg, connected by a light string. The string passes over a pulley of radius r = 0.20 m and moment of inertia I = 0.05 kg⋅m². The pulley is free to rotate without friction about a horizontal axis. If the system is released from rest, what is the total angular momentum of the system when the 5.0 kg mass has descended through a height of 1.5 m? Assume g = 9.81 m/s².

A bucket with a mass of 15.0 kg containing water is being lowered into a well. It is connected by a light rope to a counterweight of 5.0 kg. The rope wraps around a cylindrical drum at the top of the well, which has a radius of 0.30 m and a moment of inertia of 0.80 kg⋅m². Assuming the system starts from rest, calculate the total angular momentum of the system when the bucket has descended 4.0 m. Use g = 9.81 m/s².

An elevator system is designed with an elevator car of mass M = 600 kg and a counterweight of mass m = 400 kg. They are connected by a steel cable that runs over a large, frictionless pulley with a radius of 0.75 m and a moment of inertia I = 250 kg⋅m². If the elevator car starts from rest and descends 8.0 m, what is the total angular momentum of the entire system (car, counterweight, and pulley) at that point? Take g = 9.81 m/s².

An industrial crane is used to move two loads. A heavy component of mass M = 250 kg is being lowered, while a lighter counterbalancing load of mass m = 100 kg is simultaneously lifted. The cable passes over a large drum with a radius of 0.40 m and a moment of inertia I = 30 kg⋅m². If the system is released from rest, find the total angular momentum of the system when the heavy component has descended through a vertical distance of 3.0 m. Use g = 9.81 m/s².

In a physics laboratory experiment, two masses, M = 0.8 kg and m = 0.5 kg, are connected by a string passing over a uniform solid disc (pulley) that can rotate freely. The disc has a radius of 0.15 m and a moment of inertia I = 0.018 kg⋅m². Starting from rest, the 0.8 kg mass descends. Determine the total angular momentum of the two masses and the disc when the 0.8 kg mass has moved down a distance of 0.7 m. Assume g = 9.81 m/s².

A small probe (mass 100 kg) is in a circular orbit of radius 7.0 x 10^6 m around a much larger celestial body, with an orbital speed of 7.5 x 10^3 m/s. Due to a specialized radial thruster system that exerts no torque, its orbital radius is slowly reduced to 6.5 x 10^6 m. Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the probe.

An electron (mass 9.109 x 10^-31 kg) is circulating in a uniform magnetic field, moving in a circular path of radius 1.0 x 10^-3 m with a speed of 2.0 x 10^6 m/s. A slowly varying radial electric field is then applied, which draws the electron inward to a radius of 0.5 x 10^-3 m without exerting any torque. Find the magnitude of the inward radial force on the electron at this new radius.

An ice skater with an effective mass of 60 kg is spinning on a frictionless ice surface with her arms outstretched, giving her an effective radius of 1.2 m from the axis of rotation and a tangential speed of 1.5 m/s at that radius. She then pulls her arms in, decreasing her effective radius to 0.4 m. Calculate the change in her kinetic energy.

A small ball of mass 0.5 kg is placed on a smooth (frictionless) horizontal rotating platform and is attached to a string that passes through a small hole at the center of the platform. Initially, the ball moves in a circular path of radius 0.8 m with a speed of 2.0 m/s. A motor beneath the platform slowly pulls the string, decreasing the radius of the ball's path to 0.2 m. Determine the tension in the string when the ball moves at this new radius.

A small, dense particle with a mass of 0.01 kg is observed moving in a circular path of radius 0.3 m with a tangential speed of 0.5 m/s within an ideal fluid vortex. As the fluid drains, the vortex tightens, and the particle's circular path is slowly reduced to a radius of 0.1 m. Assuming angular momentum of the particle is conserved, calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the particle.

A 500 kg satellite is in a stable circular orbit around a planet at an initial radius of 7.0 x 10^6 m, moving with a speed of 7.5 x 10^3 m/s. Due to a small thruster firing, its orbit is slowly contracted to a new circular radius of 6.0 x 10^6 m. (a) Find the gravitational force acting on the satellite at the new radius. (b) Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the satellite.

A 25 kg child is initially standing on a large, frictionless merry-go-round at a distance of 3.0 m from the center. The merry-go-round is rotating such that the child's initial tangential speed is 2.0 m/s. An adult slowly guides the child inwards to a new radius of 1.5 m. (a) Find the magnitude of the centripetal force exerted on the child at the new radius. (b) Calculate the change in the child's kinetic energy.

A 0.8 kg tetherball is initially swinging in a horizontal circle with a radius of 1.2 m at a speed of 3.0 m/s. The rope slowly wraps around the central pole, effectively decreasing the radius of the ball's path to 0.6 m. (a) Find the tension in the rope when the ball is at the smaller radius. (b) Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the tetherball.

An isolated spherical dust cloud, modeled as a point mass of 2.0 x 10^20 kg, is initially orbiting the center of a protogalaxy in a circular path of radius 5.0 x 10^19 m with a tangential speed of 1.0 x 10^4 m/s. Due to gravitational interaction with other matter, its orbit slowly contracts to a radius of 2.5 x 10^19 m. (a) Find the net gravitational force acting on the dust cloud at the new radius. (b) Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the dust cloud.

A 0.2 kg object is placed on a frictionless platform of a laboratory centrifugal apparatus and is attached to a central post by a retractable cord. Initially, it moves in a circle of radius 0.40 m with a tangential speed of 1.5 m/s. The cord is slowly retracted until the object's radius is 0.25 m. (a) Find the tension in the cord when the object moves at the smaller radius. (b) Calculate the change in the kinetic energy of the object.

A uniform thin disk of mass 2 kg and radius 0.4 m is pivoted freely at a point on its rim. It is initially held in a horizontal position (with its center of mass horizontally aligned with the pivot) and then released. Determine its angular speed when it reaches its lowest vertical position.

A uniform rod of mass 3 kg and length 1.2 m is pivoted at a point located 0.3 m from one of its ends. The rod is initially held horizontally and then released. Calculate the linear speed of the end furthest from the pivot when it swings through its lowest vertical position.

A uniform rod of mass 2 kg and length 1 m is pivoted at one end. A point mass of 1 kg is attached to the free end of the rod. The system is initially held horizontally and then released from rest. Calculate the angular speed of the system when it swings through its lowest vertical position.

A uniform thin annular disk has an outer radius of 0.5 m and an inner radius of 0.2 m. It is pivoted at a point on its outer rim. The disk is initially held such that its center of mass is at an angle of 60 degrees from the vertical (above the lowest point) and then released. Find its angular speed when it passes through its lowest vertical position.

Two thin uniform rods, Rod A (mass 1 kg, length 0.6 m) and Rod B (mass 1.5 kg, length 0.8 m), are rigidly joined at one end to form an 'L' shape. The system is pivoted at the corner. Initially, Rod A is held horizontally and Rod B hangs vertically downwards. The system is then released from rest. Determine its angular speed when Rod A also hangs vertically downwards.

A uniform thin disk of mass 5 kg and radius 0.5 m is mounted such that it can freely rotate about a horizontal axis passing through a point on its rim. The disk is initially held vertically with its center of mass directly above the pivot point. It is then released from rest. What is the angular speed of the disk when its center of mass is passing through its lowest possible position? Also, what is the linear speed of the point on the rim diametrically opposite to the pivot at this instant? (Use g = 9.81 m/s^2)

A uniform plank of wood, with a mass of 2 kg and a length of 1.5 m, is hinged at one of its ends to a wall, allowing it to swing freely in a vertical plane. Initially, the plank is held perfectly horizontally. It is then released from rest and allowed to swing downwards under gravity. Determine the angular speed of the plank when it passes through its lowest vertical position. What is the linear speed of its free end at this moment? (Use g = 9.81 m/s^2)

A compound pendulum consists of a uniform rod of mass 1 kg and length 1.2 m, with a small, dense sphere of mass 3 kg attached to its free end. The rod is pivoted at its other end and is initially held vertically upwards, with the sphere at its highest point. It is released from rest and allowed to swing downwards. Calculate the angular speed of the rod-sphere system when it passes through its lowest vertical position. What is the linear speed of the attached sphere at this instant? (Use g = 9.81 m/s^2)

A uniform rigid rod of mass 3 kg and length 2 m is pivoted about a horizontal axis located 0.5 m from its geometric center. The rod is initially held in a horizontal position and then released from rest. Find the angular speed of the rod as it swings to its lowest vertical position. What is the linear speed of the lowest point of the rod at this instant? (Use g = 9.81 m/s^2)

A drawbridge, modeled as a uniform rectangular plate of mass 50 kg and effective height 1.0 m (the dimension that swings), is hinged along one of its long edges. The bridge is initially held in a horizontal position (closed) and is then released to fall under gravity. Determine the angular speed of the drawbridge just as it reaches a fully vertical (open downwards) position. What is the linear speed of its free (bottom) edge at this point? (Use g = 9.81 m/s^2)

A hypothetical satellite constellation consists of four identical small satellites, each with a mass of 50 kg. At a specific moment, these satellites are positioned such that they form the corners of a square with a side length of 50 meters. Calculate the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the square and passing through its geometric center.

A specialized high-speed camera rotor is designed to hold four identical sensor modules. Each sensor module can be approximated as a point mass of 0.5 kg. The modules are mounted at the corners of a square, with a side length of 0.5 meters, on a massless frame. Determine the moment of inertia of the system about a central axis perpendicular to the plane of the square and passing through its center.

Consider a conceptual design for a miniature Ferris wheel where four identical gondolas, each having a total mass of 20 kg (including passengers), are attached to the corners of a square-shaped frame. The side length of this square is 3 meters. Assuming the frame itself is massless and the gondolas are point masses, what is the moment of inertia of the system about the central axle, which is perpendicular to the plane of the square?

In a theoretical model of an asteroid cluster, four equally massive asteroids, each with a mass of 5.0 x 10^9 kg, are arranged in a rigid configuration forming the corners of a square in deep space. The side length of this square is 2.0 x 10^3 meters. Calculate the moment of inertia of this asteroid cluster about an axis passing through its center of mass and perpendicular to the plane defined by the square.

A robotic arm's end-effector is equipped with four identical tools, each modeled as a point mass of 0.75 kg. These tools are positioned precisely at the corners of a square, creating a side length of 0.30 meters between adjacent tools. If the end-effector rotates about a central axis perpendicular to the plane of the tools and passing through the center of the square, calculate the moment of inertia of the tool system.

Three identical small spheres, each of mass 0.25 kg, are placed at the corners of an equilateral triangle with a side length of 0.6 m. Calculate the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the triangle and passing through its centroid.

A decorative light fixture has six identical light bulbs, each with an effective mass of 0.1 kg, arranged symmetrically at the vertices of a regular hexagon. If the side length of the hexagon is 0.4 m, what is the moment of inertia of the bulbs about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the hexagon and passing through its geometric center?

A square-shaped drone frame, with a side length of 0.8 m, has four identical motors, each of mass 1.5 kg, mounted at its corners. Determine the moment of inertia of this system of motors about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the drone frame and passing through one of its corners.

In a conceptual model of a 2D crystal, four identical atoms, each treated as a point mass of 0.5 kg, are situated at the corners of a square unit cell with a side length of 1.2 m. Find the moment of inertia of these atoms about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the unit cell and passing through the midpoint of one of its sides.

Five identical small magnets, each with a mass of 0.2 kg, are arranged to form a regular pentagon with a side length of 0.7 m. Calculate the moment of inertia of this system of magnets about an axis perpendicular to the plane of the pentagon and passing through its centroid.

Two identical thin circular disks, each of mass 2.0 kg and radius 15.0 cm, are fixed at the ends of a light rod of length 60.0 cm. The planes of the disks are perpendicular to the rod. Calculate the moment of inertia of the system about an axis perpendicular to the rod passing through its middle point.

A dumbbell-like structure is formed by two identical hollow spherical shells, each of mass 0.8 kg and radius 12.0 cm, joined by a light rod of length 40.0 cm. The rod connects their centers. Determine the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its center.

Two small, dense lead weights, each treated as a point mass of 5.0 kg, are attached to the ends of a light rod that is 1.0 m long. Find the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its exact center.

Consider a composite rod assembly made of two identical uniform rods, each of mass 3.0 kg and length 80.0 cm, joined end-to-end to form a single longer rod. The junction point is at the center of the entire assembly. What is the moment of inertia of this assembly about an axis perpendicular to its length and passing through the junction point?

Two identical uniform solid cubes, each with a mass of 4.0 kg and a side length of 20.0 cm, are mounted on a light rod of length 70.0 cm. The cubes are fixed at the ends of the rod such that the rod passes through their centers of mass. The axis of rotation for the system passes through the middle point of the rod and is perpendicular to it. Calculate the moment of inertia of this system.

A metallic dumbbell consists of two identical solid spheres, each of mass 2.5 kg and radius 8.0 cm. They are connected by a light rigid rod, with the centers of the spheres separated by a distance of 40.0 cm. Calculate the moment of inertia of this dumbbell about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its middle point.

An industrial machine incorporates two identical solid cylindrical flywheels, each having a mass of 10.0 kg, a radius of 15.0 cm, and a length of 5.0 cm. These flywheels are attached at the ends of a light shaft such that their centers are separated by 80.0 cm. Determine the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the shaft, passing through its midpoint. Assume the shaft connects the centers of the circular faces of the cylinders.

For a spaceborne antenna array, two identical circular dishes, each modeled as a thin ring of mass 0.8 kg and radius 25.0 cm, are mounted at the ends of a light boom. The separation between the centers of the dishes is 120.0 cm. Find the moment of inertia of this array about an axis perpendicular to the boom and passing through its center. Assume the dishes are oriented such that the axis of rotation for their individual moment of inertia (about their center of mass) is along their diameter.

A rotational training system for astronauts utilizes two identical hollow spheres, each of mass 1.5 kg and radius 12.0 cm. They are rigidly connected by a light rod, with a center-to-center separation of 70.0 cm. Calculate the moment of inertia of this system about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through its midpoint.

A demonstrator for rotational dynamics is constructed with two identical solid spheres, each of mass 1.0 kg and radius 6.0 cm, fixed to a light rod. The centers of the spheres are separated by 60.0 cm. Determine the moment of inertia of the system about an axis perpendicular to the rod and passing through the center of one of the spheres.

A specialized drone frame is constructed from two uniform, identical carbon fiber beams. Each beam has a mass of 2.0 kg and a length of 1.5 meters. These beams are joined at their centers to form a cross shape. Calculate the moment of inertia of this drone frame about an axis passing through its center and bisecting the angle between the two beams, as indicated by a dotted line in a design diagram.

In a robotic manipulator arm, two identical links, each modeled as a uniform rod, are rigidly connected at their midpoints to form a cross-shaped attachment. Each link has a mass of 0.8 kg and a length of 0.6 meters. Determine the moment of inertia of this attachment about an axis that passes through the joint (center) and makes a 45-degree angle with each link.

A conceptual design for a modular space station includes a core module with two identical, uniform structural struts extending outwards, forming a cross. Each strut has a mass of 15.0 kg and a length of 4.0 meters. Assuming the struts lie in a single plane, find the moment of inertia of this two-strut assembly about an axis that passes through the central connection point and bisects the angle between the struts.

For a large wind turbine blade assembly, two identical, uniform support spars, each with a mass of 1.2 kg and a length of 0.8 meters, are joined at their centers to create a cruciform structure. This structure is intended to be rotated during maintenance. Calculate the moment of inertia of this cruciform structure about an axis that passes through the center point and lies in the plane of the spars, bisecting the angle between them.

A demonstrative physics apparatus is built using two identical, thin metallic rods. Each rod has a mass of 0.5 kg and a length of 1.0 meter. They are permanently fixed at their midpoints to form a perfect cross. What is the moment of inertia of this combined system about an axis that passes through the intersection point of the rods and bisects the angle formed by them?

A newly designed satellite component consists of two identical deployable solar panel arms, each of mass 15 kg and length 3.0 m. When fully extended, they form a perfect cross shape. Determine the moment of inertia of this solar panel assembly about an axis that bisects the angle between the two arms, passing through their common center.

A simplified model of a large wind turbine rotor uses two uniform, identical blades, each with a mass of 500 kg and a length of 20.0 m. These blades are attached to the hub such that they form a cross. Calculate the moment of inertia of this two-blade rotor about an axis lying in the plane of the blades and passing through the central hub, bisecting the angle between the blades.

For a laboratory experiment, a molecular model is constructed using two identical rod-like structures, each of mass 0.5 kg and length 1.5 m. These structures are joined at their centers to form a cross. Find the moment of inertia of this model about an axis that passes through the junction point and makes an angle of 45 degrees with either rod, remaining in the plane of the model.

A robotic arm's end-effector utilizes a structural cross-brace made of two uniform, identical members. Each member has a mass of 2.5 kg and a length of 0.8 m. If these members are joined at their midpoints to form a cross, what is the moment of inertia of this cross-brace about an axis passing through its center and lying in its plane, specifically bisecting the angle formed by the members?

A precision balance scale features a cross-shaped central arm structure, fabricated from two identical uniform beams. Each beam has a mass of 0.5 kg and a length of 1.2 m. If the beams are rigidly joined at their centers to form a right-angled cross, calculate the moment of inertia of this entire cross-arm assembly about an axis that passes through the center of the cross, lies in the plane of the beams, and bisects the angle between them.

A uniform solar panel of mass 20 kg and length 4 m is free-floating in space. A piece of space debris of mass 0.5 kg moving at a speed of 7000 m/s perpendicular to the length of the panel strikes it at a distance of 1 m from its centre and stops after the collision. Find (a) the velocity of the centre of mass of the panel and (b) the angular velocity of the panel about its centre just after the collision.

A uniform rectangular barrier of mass 2.5 kg and length 1.2 m rests on a frictionless surface. A hockey puck of mass 0.17 kg moving at a speed of 40 m/s perpendicular to the length of the barrier strikes it at a distance of 0.3 m from its centre and stops after the collision. Find (a) the velocity of the centre of mass of the barrier and (b) the angular velocity of the barrier about its centre just after the collision.

A uniform wooden plank of mass 5 kg and length 2 m lies on a smooth icy surface. A small high-speed projectile of mass 0.01 kg moving at a speed of 800 m/s perpendicular to the length of the plank strikes it at a distance of 0.5 m from the centre and stops after the collision. Find (a) the velocity of the centre of mass of the plank and (b) the angular velocity of the plank about its centre just after the collision.

A uniform snooker table rail section of mass 1.5 kg and length 1.8 m is free to move on a frictionless table. A cue ball of mass 0.16 kg moving at a speed of 5 m/s perpendicular to the length of the rail strikes it at a distance of 0.45 m from its centre and stops after the collision. Find (a) the velocity of the centre of mass of the rail and (b) the angular velocity of the rail about its centre just after the collision.

A uniform cylindrical space station module segment of mass 50 kg and length 6 m is floating freely in space. A meteorite fragment of mass 0.1 kg moving at a speed of 10000 m/s perpendicular to the length of the module strikes it at a distance of 1.5 m from its centre and stops after the collision. Find (a) the velocity of the centre of mass of the module and (b) the angular velocity of the module about its centre just after the collision.

A uniform wooden door of mass 20 kg and width 0.8 m is initially at rest, resting on a smooth horizontal floor. A small pellet of mass 0.01 kg, moving at a speed of 150 m/s perpendicular to the plane of the door, strikes it at a distance of 0.2 m from its center along its width. After the collision, the pellet comes to an absolute stop. Calculate the angular velocity of the door about its center just after the collision.

A long, uniform cylindrical segment of a space station, with a mass of 5000 kg and a length of 30 m, is floating at rest in deep space. A small piece of space debris, mass 0.5 kg, moving at 1000 m/s, strikes the segment perpendicularly to its length at a point 7.5 m from its center of mass. The debris effectively disintegrates upon impact, dissipating all its momentum and stopping relative to the space frame. Determine the velocity of the center of mass of the space station segment immediately after the collision.

A hockey stick, modeled as a uniform rod of mass 0.7 kg and length 1.5 m, is lying on a frictionless ice surface, initially at rest. A hockey puck of mass 0.16 kg, moving at 30 m/s perpendicular to the stick's length, strikes it at a distance of 0.375 m from the center of the stick. The puck stops dead upon impact, losing all its kinetic energy to the stick. What is the angular velocity of the hockey stick about its center just after the collision?

A uniform log of mass 200 kg and length 8 m floats at rest in still water. A small bumper boat of mass 50 kg, moving at 2 m/s parallel to the water surface and perpendicular to the log's length, strikes the log at a distance of 2 m from its center. The boat's propulsion system instantaneously reverses thrust upon impact, bringing it to an absolute stop. Find the angular velocity of the log about its center just after the collision.

A uniform rectangular target board, considered as a rod of mass 10 kg and length 1.2 m, is initially at rest on a smooth horizontal shooting range. A bullet of mass 0.005 kg, traveling at 700 m/s perpendicular to the board's length, strikes it at a distance of 0.3 m from its center. The bullet is designed to lose all its momentum and stop within a ballistic gel layer at the back of the target, without embedding or passing through, such that its final velocity is effectively zero. Calculate the velocity of the center of mass of the target board immediately after the collision.
A car tire has a diameter of 65 cm. If the car is traveling at a constant speed of 108 km/h, calculate the rotational speed of the tire in revolutions per minute (RPM).
A conveyor belt system moves items at a constant linear speed of 1.5 m/s. The belt is driven by a roller with a radius of 20 cm. Determine the angular speed of the roller in revolutions per second.

A construction winch is used to pull a heavy load at a steady linear speed of 0.8 m/s. The cable is wound onto a cylindrical drum that has a diameter of 30 cm. What is the rotational frequency of the drum in revolutions per second?

An old magnetic tape player pulls tape past the read head at a constant speed of 4.76 cm/s. If the take-up reel, when nearly full, has an effective outer diameter of 5.0 cm, what is its rotational speed in revolutions per minute (RPM) at that instant?
On a bicycle, the rear sprocket has a diameter of 15 cm. If the chain moves over the sprocket at a linear speed of 4.5 m/s, what is the rotational speed of the sprocket in revolutions per second?
A conveyor belt moves at a constant speed of 1.2 m/s. If packages, each 40 cm long, are placed end-to-end on the belt, how many packages pass a fixed point per second?

A digital communication channel transmits data at a steady rate of 100 megabits per second (Mbps). If each data packet is 1000 bytes long, how many packets are transmitted per second? (Note: 1 byte = 8 bits)

Water flows from a tap into a tank at a constant volumetric flow rate of 300 liters per minute. If a small container has a volume of 5 liters, how many such containers can be filled per second by this flow?

A manufacturing machine feeds a continuous strip of metal at a speed of 20 cm/s. If the machine cuts individual components, each 5 cm long, from this strip, how many components are produced per second?

A magnetic tape drive reads data at a constant speed where the tape moves past the read head at 1.5 m/s. If each data block recorded on the tape occupies a physical length of 3 cm, how many data blocks are read per second?

A solid spherical ball is released from rest at a vertical height of 2.5 meters on a smooth curved track. If it rolls without slipping, what will be its speed when it reaches the lowest point of the track?

A thin ring, acting like a giant yo-yo, is released from rest and unwinds a massless string from its outer radius as it falls. If the ring falls through a vertical distance of 4 meters, what will be the speed of its center of mass at that point? Assume it unwinds without slipping.

A solid homogeneous disk (flywheel) of mass 10 kg and radius 0.3 m is mounted on a frictionless horizontal axle. A light string is wrapped around its circumference, and a 2 kg block is attached to the free end. If the block is released from rest and falls 1.5 meters, what will be the speed of the block at that instant?

A bicycle wheel, effectively modeled as a thin ring of mass M and radius R, is initially at rest at the top of a ramp. The ramp has an inclination of 28 degrees and a length of 7 meters. If the wheel rolls down without slipping, what will be the speed of its center of mass when it reaches the bottom?

A bowling ball (solid sphere) is rolled up an incline with an initial translational speed of 8 m/s. The incline makes an angle of 35 degrees with the horizontal. Assuming the ball rolls without slipping, how far up the incline will it travel before momentarily coming to rest?

A solid sphere of mass 2 kg and radius 10 cm is released from rest from the top of an incline. The incline has a length of 15 meters and an angle of inclination of 25 degrees. Assuming the sphere rolls without slipping, what will be its speed when it reaches the bottom of the incline?

A hollow cylindrical shell, with a mass of 1.5 kg and an outer radius of 8 cm, is allowed to roll without slipping down a ramp that is 8 meters long and inclined at an angle of 35 degrees to the horizontal. Calculate the speed of the hollow cylinder when it reaches the base of the ramp.

A child's yo-yo, which can be modeled as a solid disk of mass 0.1 kg, is released from rest with its string unrolling downwards from the top of a table. If the yo-yo descends a vertical distance of 1.2 meters, what will be its translational speed just before the string fully unrolls? Assume it rolls without slipping along the string.

An empty bowling ball (approximated as a thin spherical shell) of mass 4 kg and radius 15 cm starts from rest at the top of a smoothly curved track. If the vertical height difference between the starting point and the lowest point of the track is 2.5 meters, what is the speed of the bowling ball at the lowest point, assuming it rolls without slipping?

A uniform disc of mass 0.5 kg and radius 20 cm is placed at rest on a sloping surface. The vertical height of the slope is 3 meters. If the disc rolls down without slipping, determine the speed it will acquire upon reaching the bottom of the slope.
A solid cylinder of mass 2 kg and radius 10 cm rolls without slipping down an inclined plane making an angle of 30 degrees with the horizontal. Calculate the linear acceleration of the cylinder.

A large ring (hoop) of mass 5 kg and radius 0.5 m is pulled by a horizontal force of 20 N applied at its center of mass, causing it to roll without slipping on a rough horizontal surface. What is the minimum coefficient of static friction required for pure rolling?

A solid cylinder of mass 6 kg and radius 20 cm rests on a horizontal surface. A string is wrapped around the cylinder and passes over a light, frictionless pulley, with a 3 kg mass hanging vertically from its end. Assuming the cylinder rolls without slipping, calculate the linear acceleration of the hanging mass.

A hollow sphere (spherical shell) is placed on an inclined plane. If the coefficient of static friction between the sphere and the plane is 0.4, determine the maximum inclination angle (in degrees) of the plane for which the sphere will roll without slipping.
A hollow cylinder of mass 4 kg and radius 15 cm rolls without slipping down an inclined plane at an angle of 60 degrees to the horizontal. Calculate the linear acceleration of the cylinder.
A solid cylinder of mass 3 kg and radius 10 cm rolls without slipping down an inclined plane of inclination 30 degrees. Calculate its linear acceleration.

A thin-walled hollow sphere of mass 2 kg and radius 15 cm rolls without slipping down an inclined plane with an inclination of 37 degrees. Determine the magnitude of the friction force acting on the sphere. (Use sin(37) = 0.60 and cos(37) = 0.80 for calculations).

A ring of mass 1 kg and radius 5 cm is placed on an inclined plane set at 45 degrees to the horizontal. What is the minimum coefficient of static friction required for the ring to roll down the plane without slipping?

A solid cylinder rolls without slipping down an inclined plane of inclination 30 degrees. Its linear acceleration is found to be 3.27 m/s^2. If a solid sphere were to roll without slipping down the exact same inclined plane, what would be its linear acceleration?

A solid cylinder, with mass 5 kg and radius 8 cm, is released from rest and rolls without slipping down an inclined plane with an angle of 30 degrees. How much time does it take for the cylinder to travel a distance of 10 meters along the incline?

An industrial motor shaft, with a moment of inertia of 1.0 kg·m² and an attached clutch plate of effective radius 0.2 m, is rotating at an angular speed of 150 rad/s. It is moved closer to engage a smaller gearbox input shaft, which has a moment of inertia of 0.025 kg·m² and an attached clutch plate of effective radius 0.1 m. The gearbox input shaft is initially at rest. Due to friction between the clutch plates, slip ceases and both shafts eventually rotate together at compatible tangential speeds. Find the final angular speed of the motor shaft.

A large gas turbine rotor, with a moment of inertia of 1000 kg·m² and an effective clutch engagement radius of 0.8 m, is spinning at 500 rad/s. It engages with a smaller auxiliary generator rotor, which has a moment of inertia of 50 kg·m² and an effective clutch engagement radius of 0.2 m. The auxiliary generator rotor is initially stationary. Friction between the engaging surfaces brings them to a no-slip condition. Calculate the final angular speed of the turbine rotor.

A potter's wheel, modeled as a disc with a moment of inertia of 5.0 kg·m², is rotating at 10 rad/s. A small, unpowered shaping tool, designed with a contact wheel of effective radius 0.05 m and moment of inertia 0.01 kg·m², is brought down onto the rim of the potter's wheel (effective contact radius 0.3 m). Friction between the tool wheel and the potter's wheel causes them to reach a state where there is no slip at the contact point. Determine the final angular speed of the potter's wheel.

In a roller coaster ride, a main drive wheel with a moment of inertia of 20 kg·m² and a radius of 0.5 m is rotating at 10 rad/s. It comes into contact with an idle wheel, which has a moment of inertia of 0.5 kg·m² and a radius of 0.1 m, initially at rest. Friction between the wheels ensures that they eventually rotate without slipping. What is the final angular speed of the main drive wheel?

A primary gear in a robotic arm, with a pitch radius of 0.08 m and a moment of inertia (including motor contribution) of 0.02 kg·m², is spinning at 50 rad/s. A secondary, unpowered gear with a pitch radius of 0.03 m and a moment of inertia of 0.005 kg·m² is then meshed with it. Assuming no slip between the gear teeth once engaged, find the final angular speed of the primary gear.

Two large industrial discs, rotating about parallel vertical axes, are brought into contact at their edges. Disc 1 has a mass of 50 kg and a radius of 0.8 m, initially rotating at 15 rad/s. Disc 2 has a mass of 30 kg and a radius of 0.5 m, initially rotating at 25 rad/s. Assuming both are uniform solid cylinders and friction between them brings their tangential speeds at the contact point to a synchronized state, what is the final angular speed of Disc 1?

A heavy flywheel (Flywheel A) with a moment of inertia of 10 kg m^2 is spinning at 100 rpm. Another lighter flywheel (Flywheel B) with a moment of inertia of 5 kg m^2 is initially at rest. The flywheels are brought together such that their friction coupling surfaces, with radii of 0.3 m for Flywheel A and 0.2 m for Flywheel B, touch. If slip eventually ceases, what is the final angular speed of Flywheel A in rad/s?

During a simulated docking maneuver, two cylindrical space station modules, both initially rotating, make contact. The larger module (Module A) has a mass of 10000 kg and a radius of 5 m, rotating at 0.01 rad/s. The smaller module (Module B) has a mass of 1000 kg and a radius of 1 m, rotating at 0.1 rad/s. If they are assumed to be uniform solid cylinders and friction at their contact points causes them to synchronize their tangential velocities, what is the final angular speed of Module A?

In a conveyor belt drive system, a main drive roller (solid cylinder) with a mass of 100 kg and a radius of 0.5 m is rotating at 20 rad/s. An idler roller (solid cylinder), initially at rest, has a mass of 20 kg and a radius of 0.2 m. The idler roller is pressed against the main drive roller, and friction causes it to spin up until there is no slip at their contact point. What is the final angular speed of the idler roller?

Two components within a high-speed centrifugal separator are designed to operate with synchronized tangential speeds. The main rotor (approximated as a solid cylinder) has a mass of 15 kg and a radius of 0.2 m, initially spinning at 50 rad/s. A smaller auxiliary cylinder (also a solid cylinder) has a mass of 2 kg and a radius of 0.05 m, initially spinning at 100 rad/s. When they are brought into contact, friction causes them to synchronize. Calculate the final angular speed of the auxiliary cylinder.

A large, hollow cylindrical cable spool of mass 150 kg and radius 0.4 m is suspended vertically by a single strong cable wrapped around its circumference. If the spool is released from rest and unwinds as it falls, find the speed of the spool after it has fallen a vertical distance of 10 m. (Assume the spool can be modeled as a thin hollow cylinder, where its moment of inertia I = MR². Use g = 9.8 m/s²).

A light, inextensible rope is wrapped around a massive solid cylindrical pulley of mass 20 kg and radius 0.2 m, which is free to rotate about a fixed, frictionless horizontal axle. A block of mass 5 kg is attached to the free end of the rope. If the block is released from rest, find its speed after it has fallen a vertical distance of 5 m. (Use g = 9.8 m/s²).

A solid sphere of mass 10 kg and radius 0.1 m starts from rest and rolls without slipping down an inclined plane that makes an angle of 30 degrees with the horizontal. Find the speed of the sphere's center of mass after it has rolled a distance of 4 m along the incline. (For a solid sphere, the moment of inertia I = (2/5)MR². Use g = 9.8 m/s²).

A bicycle wheel of mass 2 kg and radius 0.3 m is approximated as a thin hoop (ring). It is suspended vertically by two strings wrapped around its rim, similar to how a cylinder is suspended by two strings. If the wheel is released from rest and unwinds as it falls, calculate its speed after it has fallen a vertical distance of 3 m. (For a thin hoop, the moment of inertia I = MR². Use g = 9.8 m/s²).

A yo-yo, modeled as a solid cylinder of total mass 1 kg and outer radius 0.1 m, has a string wrapped around its central axle of radius 0.01 m. The yo-yo is held at rest with the string vertical and then released. Find the speed of the yo-yo's center of mass after it has fallen a vertical distance of 1.5 m. (Assume the effective moment of inertia for the yo-yo's rotation is I = (1/2)MR_outer², where R_outer is the outer radius. Use g = 9.8 m/s²).

A yo-yo, modeled as a uniform solid disk of mass 0.25 kg and radius 0.04 m, is released from rest with its string fixed at the top. The string unwinds as the yo-yo falls. (a) Calculate the acceleration of the yo-yo. (b) What is the speed of the yo-yo after it has dropped 0.5 meters?

A massive industrial spool, modeled as a solid cylinder of mass 50 kg and radius 0.3 m, rests on a rough factory floor. A worker pulls a string wrapped around its circumference horizontally with a constant force of 490.5 N. Assuming the spool rolls without slipping, (a) calculate its acceleration. (b) Determine its speed after it has moved a horizontal distance of 2.0 meters.

An Atwood machine consists of a block of mass 10 kg connected by a string that passes over a massive pulley. The pulley is a uniform solid disk of mass 10 kg and radius 0.15 m, fixed to a support and rotating about a frictionless axle. The block is released from rest. (a) Find the acceleration of the block. (b) What is the speed of the block after it has fallen a vertical distance of 3.0 meters?

A uniform solid cylinder of mass 20 kg and radius 0.2 m is placed on a rough horizontal table. A string is wrapped around its circumference, passes horizontally over a massless, frictionless pulley, and is attached to a hanging mass of 60 kg. The cylinder rolls without slipping. (a) Calculate the acceleration of the cylinder. (b) Determine the speed of the cylinder after it has rolled a distance of 1.5 meters.

A solid cylindrical log of mass 120 kg and radius 0.4 m rolls without slipping down a very rough inclined plane. If it starts from rest and descends through a vertical height of 2.5 meters, what is its speed at the bottom of the incline?

A uniform solid cylinder of mass 3 kg rests on a rough horizontal plane. A horizontal force of 15 N is applied tangentially at its topmost point. Assuming the cylinder rolls without slipping, what is the acceleration of its center of mass?

A thin circular ring (hoop) of mass 4 kg is placed on a rough horizontal surface. A constant horizontal force of 20 N is exerted tangentially at the highest point of the ring. If the ring rolls without slipping, determine the acceleration of its center.

A solid sphere of mass 2 kg is on a rough horizontal surface. A horizontal force of 14 N is applied directly at its center of mass. If the sphere rolls without slipping, calculate the acceleration of the sphere's center.

A uniform solid cylinder of mass 5 kg is on a rough horizontal plane. A horizontal force of 25 N is applied tangentially at a point located halfway between its center of mass and its highest point. Assuming the cylinder rolls without slipping, find the acceleration of its center of mass.

A thin spherical shell of mass 6 kg is placed on a rough horizontal plane. A horizontal force of 30 N is applied tangentially at a point located halfway between its center of mass and its lowest point. If the shell rolls without slipping, what is the acceleration of its center of mass?

A bowling ball, modeled as a solid sphere, has a mass of 6 kg and a radius of 0.12 m. It is placed on a rough horizontal lane. A player applies a horizontal force of 42 N tangentially at the very top of the ball. Assuming the ball rolls without slipping, what is the acceleration of its center of mass?

An industrial roller, idealized as a solid cylinder with a mass of 20 kg and a radius of 0.2 m, rests on a factory floor. A worker pushes it with a horizontal force of 90 N, applied tangentially at the highest point of the cylinder. If the roller moves without slipping, determine the acceleration of its central axis.

A lightweight spherical drum, essentially a hollow sphere, has a mass of 5 kg and a radius of 0.3 m. It is placed on a rough horizontal surface. A horizontal force of 30 N is applied tangentially at the uppermost point of the drum. Assuming it rolls without slipping, calculate the acceleration of the drum's center.

A spherical cannonball, treated as a solid sphere of mass 15 kg and radius 0.1 m, is resting on a very rough horizontal ground. A horizontal force of 105 N is applied directly through its center of mass. If the cannonball rolls without slipping, what is the acceleration of its center of mass?

A large glass marble, modeled as a solid sphere of mass 0.05 kg and radius 0.01 m, is on a rough horizontal table. A small horizontal constant force of 0.35 N is applied directly at the lowest point of the marble (its point of contact with the table). If the marble rolls without slipping, determine the acceleration of its center.

A solid cylinder of mass 2M and radius R = 0.2 m is sliding and rotating on a rough horizontal surface. At a certain instant, its center of mass has a translational velocity of 10 m/s, and it has an angular velocity of 15 rad/s in the direction of forward rotation. Determine the translational velocity of its center of mass once pure rolling motion is achieved.

A hollow sphere (thin spherical shell) of mass M and radius R = 0.1 m is placed on a rough horizontal conveyor belt. Initially, the sphere has a forward translational velocity of 5 m/s and an angular velocity of 80 rad/s (in the direction that causes backward slipping). Assuming the conveyor belt is stationary, find the translational velocity of the sphere's center of mass when it begins to roll without slipping.

A thin hoop of mass m and radius R = 0.5 m is released onto a rough horizontal floor. At the moment of release, it has a forward translational velocity of 8 m/s, but it is rotating backward with an angular velocity of 5 rad/s. Calculate the final translational velocity of the hoop's center of mass once it transitions to pure rolling motion.

A bowling ball (solid sphere) with mass m and radius R = 0.3 m is thrown onto a rough horizontal lane. Initially, it has a translational velocity of 12 m/s and an angular velocity of 60 rad/s, causing it to slip backward relative to the lane surface. What will be the translational velocity of the bowling ball when it starts pure rolling?

A solid disk of mass M and radius R = 0.4 m is propelled across a rough horizontal table. At a particular moment, the disk has a translational velocity of 15 m/s and an angular velocity of 18.75 rad/s (in the forward direction of rotation, causing forward slipping). Find the translational velocity of the disk's center of mass after it reaches a state of pure rolling.

A solid uniform cylinder of mass M and radius R is placed on a rough horizontal surface. It is initially sliding forward with a translational velocity of 3.0 m/s. Simultaneously, it has an angular velocity such that the tangential speed at its lowest point due to rotation is 6.0 m/s in the direction of its translational motion (i.e., it is 'over-spinning' causing backward slip). Determine its translational velocity when it begins to roll without slipping.

A thin circular hoop of mass M and radius R is launched onto a rough horizontal floor. Initially, it has a translational velocity of 10.0 m/s but no rotational velocity. Find its translational velocity just as it begins to roll without slipping.

A hollow sphere of mass M and radius R is placed on a rough horizontal surface. It is given an initial translational velocity of 7.5 m/s in the forward direction. Simultaneously, it is given an initial angular velocity such that the tangential speed at its lowest point due to rotation is 7.5 m/s in the backward direction (i.e., it's spinning backward while moving forward). Calculate its translational velocity when it achieves pure rolling.

A uniform solid disc of mass M and radius R slides on a rough horizontal surface. At a certain moment, its center of mass moves with a velocity of 12.0 m/s, and its angular velocity is such that the tangential speed at its bottommost point due to rotation is 3.0 m/s in the same direction as its translational motion. Determine the final translational velocity of the disc once pure rolling is established.

A bowling ball (a solid sphere) of mass M and radius R is thrown onto a rough bowling lane. Initially, its translational speed is 1.4 m/s, and it is spinning rapidly backward (opposite to the direction of motion) such that its angular velocity corresponds to a tangential speed of 7.0 m/s at its bottommost point. What will be the translational velocity of the bowling ball when it starts to roll without slipping?

A stationary solid cannonball of mass 5.0 kg and radius 15 cm rests on a rough horizontal plane. A small projectile of mass 0.05 kg, traveling horizontally at a high speed, collides and sticks to the cannonball's surface. If the line of motion of the projectile is at a distance h above the plane, find the value of h for which the cannonball begins pure rolling immediately after the collision.

A solid uniform disc (flywheel) of mass 10.0 kg and radius 20 cm is initially at rest on a rough horizontal surface. A 20-gram sticky dart is fired horizontally towards the disc, impacting and embedding itself into the disc's rim. If the dart's line of motion is at a height h above the plane, determine h such that the disc starts pure rolling without slipping immediately after the impact.

A hollow spherical shell (like a large, thin-shelled ball) of mass 0.5 kg and radius 8 cm is placed on a rough horizontal surface. A pellet of mass 10 grams, moving horizontally, strikes the shell and gets embedded in its surface. If the pellet's trajectory is at a vertical distance h from the plane, calculate h for which the spherical shell commences pure rolling instantly after the collision.

A bicycle wheel, approximated as a thin hoop of mass 2.0 kg and radius 30 cm, stands upright on a rough horizontal road. A small wad of gum of mass 5 grams, moving horizontally, impacts and sticks to the outer rim of the wheel. If the line of motion of the gum is at a distance h above the road, what must be the value of h for the wheel to start pure rolling right after the impact?

Consider a uniform solid sphere of mass 0.8 kg and radius 12 cm, resting on a rough horizontal surface. A heavier pellet of mass 0.1 kg, moving horizontally, collides with the sphere and sticks to its surface. If the line of motion of the pellet is at a distance h above the plane, calculate the height h required for the sphere to achieve immediate pure rolling motion.

A solid cylinder of mass 8 kg and radius 0.25 m is placed on a rough horizontal surface. A small pellet of mass 0.01 kg traveling horizontally at 150 m/s strikes the cylinder and embeds itself. If the pellet hits at a height 'h' above the surface, find 'h' such that the cylinder immediately begins pure rolling.

A thin spherical shell of mass 12 kg and radius 0.3 m is initially at rest on a rough horizontal floor. A small projectile of mass 0.005 kg traveling at 200 m/s hits the shell and sticks to its surface. If the impact occurs at a height 'h' above the floor, determine 'h' for which the shell immediately starts pure rolling.

A massive log, which can be approximated as a solid cylinder of mass 100 kg and radius 0.4 m, is lying horizontally on a rough ground. A worker, using a special tool, fires a heavy-duty nail (mass 0.05 kg) horizontally at 300 m/s into the log. If the nail embeds itself into the log at a height 'h' above the ground, what must 'h' be so that the log begins to roll purely without slipping immediately after the impact?

A car wheel, idealized as a thin hoop of mass 15 kg and radius 0.35 m, is accidentally left in neutral on a very rough patch of ground. A small, dense pebble (mass 0.02 kg) is projected horizontally at 100 m/s towards the stationary wheel and sticks to its outer rim. If the pebble impacts the wheel at a height 'h' above the ground, calculate 'h' such that the wheel immediately starts to pure roll.

A solid rubber playground ball of mass 1.5 kg and radius 0.12 m is at rest on an asphalt court. A child throws a very small, sticky mud ball (mass 0.003 kg) horizontally at the playground ball with a speed of 25 m/s. The mud ball sticks to the surface of the playground ball. At what height 'h' above the court must the mud ball strike for the playground ball to immediately start pure rolling without slipping?
